author: Peg McNichol
title: Pet adoption encouraged by Oakland County’s near-capacity animal shelter – The Oakland Press
text:
Oakland County’s animal shelter and pet adoption center is busy and close to capacity.
There won’t be any special adoption events in the near future, said division manager Bob Gatt.
“We don’t have an event coming up because we’re so busy,” he said. “Crowd adoption events take time and staff.”

Tournament of Champions Local News | Blast levels pump house at Royal Oak’s Red Run Golf Course Local News | Flare night tradition returns to Lake Orion People can visit the shelter to adopt animals during the six days the office is open, he said.
This week the shelter had 151 dogs in the building and 130 cats – including 40 kittens Gatt described as “gorgeous” – plus more cats and dogs being fostered by volunteers in family homes.
“We’re really, really crowded and we have some great dogs here,” he said.
People who can’t adopt but would like to help in other ways can donate supplies or volunteer to be a foster home to the shelter’s dogs. This improves their social skills and their chances for a permanent home, Gatt said, adding that all food and medical care is supplied free for fostered pets.
People interested in volunteering can visit the shelter during regular hours and talk to a staff member.

Local News | A classic story: Boy meets dog, dog runs away, man and dog are reunited five and a half years later “We want to make sure the house they’re in is good for the animal they want to foster,” Gatt said. “We wouldn’t want to put a Great Dane in an apartment, for example.”
The shelter, at 1200 North Telegraph Road, Building 42E in Pontiac, is open 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays; 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. Tuesdays and Thursdays and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Saturdays. Call (248) 858-1070, email petadoption@oakgov.com or visit https://www.oakgov.com/community/pet-adoption to learn more.
